repnme.cdata!:
India - Rajasthan Second District Primary
            Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rajasthan Second
            District Primary Education Project for India were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: ownership of
            and commitment to the program at all levels is crucial to
            the development of primary education and the success of
            project implementation and realization of outcomes. It is
            extremely challenging to expand access to the remaining out
            of school children, who are from among the hardest to reach
            marginalized groups, and require innovative interventions
            such as those piloted and implemented under District Primary
            Education Program (DPEP), including the public private
            partnership initiatives. Gains in enrollment increases can
            be diluted unless there is an intensive effort to ensure
            regular student and teacher attendance, as irregular student
            attendance impacts quality and defeats the enrollment gains.
            A strong and credible monitoring system is an essential
            requirement to allow for effective planning and targeting of
            programs if necessary. Such a system is best derived from
            internal monitoring systems and field monitoring, and
            supported by external validations and evaluation studies.
            Successful implementation and sustainability is largely
            dependent on capacity in the system and in the implementing
            agency. Continuity of staff and adequate staffing of key
            institutions (such as on the quality side and monitoring)
            need to be in place to ensure effectiveness of such programs.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Second Rajasthan District Primary
            Education Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This Tribal Development Plan (TDP) for
            the Second Rajasthan District Primary Education Project is
            based on secondary information available on the project
            districts and primary information collected by the Social
            Assessments (SAs) carried out during project preparation.
            The Sas included consultations with some potential tribal
            beneficiaries of the project and with state and district
            officials and nongovernmental organizations working in the
            project areas. The TDP follows the format of the
            "Indigenous People's Development Plan,"
            provided in the World Bank's Operational Directive on
            Tribal People (O.D. 4.20). Development activities in the
            project for tribal areas and children include the following:
            a survey to identify non-schooling children; awareness
            campaigns to increase enrollment of tribal children into
            formal schools; opening alternative schools; organizing
            "bridge" course to return out-of-school children
            to formal primary education; developing a language
            inventory; distributing teacher-learning materials
            cost-free; escort services and appointing motivators to
            encourage and bring girls to school;opening early childhood
            education centers; and tuition-free education, among other
            benefits. No negative impacts are expected from the project
            as, in adition to the other strategies, tribal children will
            have access to primary education in formal primary schools
            or existing alternative schools.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Rajasthan Second District Primary
            Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rajasthan Second District Primary
            Education Project is the seventh in the series of the
            National District Primary Education Program (DPEP) (DPEP) in
            India which was launched in 1994 to target educational
            improvements in low literacy districts districts, especially
            from socially and economically disadvantaged groups, have
            access to a five-year primary education cycle of appropriate
            quality. This project is the second phase of an ongoing
            program, Rajasthan DPEP, the first phase of which is being
            financed by Rajasthan DPEP I and covers ten underserved
            districts of the state. There are three project components.
            The first expands access, retention, and enrollments. It
            includes targeted interventions to reach marginalized
            groups, establishes early childhood education centers,
            provides residential facilities for migrant children, and
            services children with mild to moderate disabilities. This
            component also provides parateachers, trains school
            management committees in community mobilization and
            awareness building and finances civil works. The second
            component institutes a pedagogical renewal approach for
            continuous support for teacher development, provides
            teaching and learning materials, and develops and provides
            school libraries and distance learning, among other actions
            to improve educational quality and achievement. The third
            component builds the capacity of the state project office to
            manage primary education at the state, district, and local levels.
